node.text:
“The earth has music for those who listen.” ~ William Shakespeare 🎵

It’s #WorldListeningDay!

How would you describe the earth’s music? What simple, or profound, messages have you received from her?

We give value to the sounds we hear—whether that is through our attention and focus, or the value or perception we afford to that sound. We can also choose to give value to the sound of, by setting aside space for—silence. 

The Grand Canyon provides us an incredible opportunity to listen. We can:
💎 Listen to the brilliant sparkle of the night skies. 
💎 Listen for birds as they express their unique songs, calls, flight patterns or movements.
💎 Listen, and feel for, when the winds start to pick up in their intensity. 
💎 Listen to the gentle caress, or raging roar, of the Colorado River as it continues its timeless generosity and continuous flow. 
💎 Listen to the Canyon open up with wonder, as the golden hues of a sunset paint the horizon in an unearthly awe. 
💎 Listen as a ranger shares with us their passion for the Canyon, as we hear their voice rise with gusto and their palpable excitement. 
💎 Listen to, and learn from, the spoken (or unspoken) histories that intimately connect indigenous people through their sacred connection to this land and this place. 

Silence is not the absence of sound but the presence of one’s ability to listen. So, today, gift yourself some moments for silence. You may find that in silence, you open up to an entire world that is waiting to share in her musical splendor with you!

For additional listening and viewing opportunities from the Grand Canyon, check out our “Minute Out In It” video series, which features compelling stories (told without words) of the diverse soundscapes and landscapes throughout the park. https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/photosmultimedia/minute-out-in-it.htm

- AB

#WorldListeningDay #ListenUp #ListenIn #Soundscapes 

[#VideoDescription: Watching cloud shadows pass lazily across the layers of the canyon during the winter season.]

NPS Video/R. Lane

An audio-described version of the film can be found here: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=772643A9-9D3B-4B0E-B6DC-D90C1DEB262E

node.title: World Listening Day: Minute Out In It In the Clouds

node.text:
Our Branch Chief of Emergency Services has an important message for you!

Grand Canyon National Park is in an Excessive Heat Warning. Inner Canyon temperatures are reaching as high as 120°F (48.9°C)! 

Your body cannot cool itself or replenish its water or salt in these conditions. Please take a look at this short video addressing heat illness, heat stroke, and how best to visit Grand Canyon during these dog days of summer.

For an audio described version and captions visit: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=A0226CAB-9569-438C-BD0C-6514B142EF28

For more information on summer hiking visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/hike-smart.htm

#RecreateResponsibly #HikeSmart

node.text:
As we get ready for Memorial Day Weekend and park visitation increases, we’d like to remind you that May is Wildland Fire Awareness Month. 

As public lands have started announcing fire restrictions in preparation for another hot and dry summer, we want to share with you a story that has become all too common. Whether you want a fire for ambience, heat, or marshmallow roasting, it is incredibly important to know if your fire is legal and safe—fires should never be started to burn waste. 

For more information and current fire restrictions visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/management/firemanagement.htm 

For closed captioned and audio described versions of this video visit: 
https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=813BBAB5-1F03-4702-8823-AF8D16D646FA 

#WildlandFireAwarenessMonth #FireSafety #MemorialDay

node.accessibility_caption: Evening views across a stormy canyon with lightning seen in the distance. NPS Photo/M. Quinn

node.text:
🚨 Heavy Rains and Thunderstorms forecasted through Monday, July 26th. Flash Flood Warning in Effect. 🚨

Monsoon season can mean conditions go from mild to wild, real quick! Monsoon weather can include sudden flash flooding, frequent lightning strikes, hail storms, torrential rains, and strong gusts of winds. ⛈⚡️💨

ℹ️ 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐔𝐩𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐞: The Bright Angel trail is open to foot traffic, in both directions. There may be short delays at some new rock slide areas, while our trail crews are working to remove debris. Currently, there are no mule trips on the Bright Angel trail until these slides are cleared. Trail crew estimates that they can clear the trail today, but that is highly dependent on today’s weather. Therefore, hikers should be prepared for debris, rock slides, and washed out sections of the trail as storms move through this area through the weekend.

⚠️ 𝐀𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐝 𝐂𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐧 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐥𝐬: The upper sections of trail are the most dangerous as these are more exposed areas and lightning tends to splash across the Kaibab Limestone. Additionally, the ground can be very unstable (saturated and constantly moving) and rock fall is a major hazard. Each year we have people get hit by rock fall, so stopping in safe locations and being very aware of your surroundings is paramount. 

👂 𝐋𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐁𝐞 𝐀𝐥𝐞𝐫𝐭: Listen for thunder, watch for lightning, and observe the direction of storm movement. Be vigilant of possible flash floods or falling rocks during or after storms. 

🏚 𝐒𝐞𝐞𝐤 𝐒𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐭𝐞𝐫: Move away from the canyon edge; leave open areas immediately; and avoid rocky outcrops, lone trees, the tallest trees, poles, railings, and bodies of water. Get to a shelter—building, vehicle with the windows closed—as quickly as possible. Do not touch rock walls or any metal on vehicles or structures. 

🧎 𝐈𝐟 𝐍𝐨 𝐈𝐦𝐦𝐞𝐝𝐢𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐒𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐭𝐞𝐫: If in an open area, such as a trail, crouch on the balls of your feet with your heels touching, head down, and hands covering ears. Your hands should not touch the ground. Do not lie flat on the ground.

node.accessibility_caption: A painting captures the canyon's interior after a thunderstorm, with storm clouds parting and golden light illuminating canyon peaks and buttes.

node.text:
"Flaming Finale" by Ralph Love - Oil on canvas. W 36 in x H 23 in. (1960's). Born in Los Angeles, Love spent his entire life in California. A primarily self-taught artist, he is well-known for his depictions of Grand Canyon. 

Applications are now open for next year's Grand Canyon Artist in Residence! We are seeking professional artists working at a high level in their discipline who can give new insights and focus to Grand Canyon and the surrounding communities as an on-site resident artist at Grand Canyon National Park. The deadline to apply for 2022 is September 15, 2021. 

Visit  grandcanyon.org/artist  for details.

Image: A painting captures the canyon's interior after a thunderstorm, with storm clouds parting and golden light illuminating canyon peaks and buttes.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 21, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.

node.text:
Grand Canyon can feel like a rather intense place to experience, at times. While we recognize this intensity, we can balance it out through moments of pause, calm, and by finding something to appreciate in this moment. 

On this #WildflowerWednesday, take a moment to connect with one thing you can appreciate right now. Tell that person, breathe in that nature, write that poem (or another creative pursuit), and create that memory. 

~💙 𝘉𝘭𝘶𝘦 𝘍𝘭𝘢𝘹 𝘏𝘢𝘪𝘬𝘶 💙~
𝘛𝘩𝘦 𝘣𝘳𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵 𝘷𝘪𝘣𝘳𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘺
𝘉𝘭𝘶𝘦 𝘧𝘭𝘢𝘹 𝘴𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘸𝘪𝘯𝘥𝘴
𝘈 𝘴𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘵 𝘴𝘰𝘶𝘯𝘥 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯

- AB

For more on Grand Canyon Wildflowers, visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/nature/wildflowers.htm

[#ImageDescription: A brightly-patterned blue flax (linum lewisii) flower springs up out of the rocky terrain. NPS Photo]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 19, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.

node.text:
On today’s Mindful Monday, we begin with a quote by Freeman Tilden from his Interpreting Our Heritage book: 

“…we know that there can be nothing ugly in nature. Nothing. The seeming exceptions are simply facets of beauty we have not yet grasped.” 

What do you think of Mr. Tilden’s quote? Are there areas of your life you can’t [yet] see as beautiful? Maybe we dislike, resist, or fear something. And all of this is okay.

But what if Mr. Tilden’s words can serve as bridge—inspiring us to see the beauty in all things.

I’ve got a question for you: 
Do you think a snake or a flower is more beautiful? For one person, their answer might be a snake. For another person, their answer might be a flower. While personally, I (the person writing this post, not representative of the entire Grand Canyon 😉) prefer the flower to the snake, can I allow another person to hold a preference for, and see the inherent beauty in, a snake? Why yes, yes I can!

Happy Mindful Monday! May the beauty of all life touch you with her essence! 💎

- AB

#MindfulMonday #NaturesBeauty #NatureInspiration #Reflection #FloraAndFauna

[#ImageDescription: Close up of a vibrant pink colored native Apache Plume shrub, botanical name Fallugia Paradoxa, set against a blue sky. NPS Photo/A. Brill]

[#ImageDescription: A white flower and pinkish globose fruits of the Apache Plume shrub, botanical name Fallugia Paradoxa. NPS Photo/White Sands National Park.]

[#ImageDescription: A Great Basin Gopher Snake, in colors of yellow and black, moves against some red rocks. NPS Photo/N. Herbert.]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 19, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.
Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 19, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.
Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 19, 2021. May be an image of snake.

node.text:
“The earth has music for those who listen.” ~ William Shakespeare 🎵

It’s #WorldListeningDay!

How would you describe the earth’s music? What simple, or profound, messages have you received from her?

We give value to the sounds we hear—whether that is through our attention and focus, or the value or perception we afford to that sound. We can also choose to give value to the sound of, by setting aside space for—silence. 

The Grand Canyon provides us an incredible opportunity to listen. We can:
💎 Listen to the brilliant sparkle of the night skies. 
💎 Listen for birds as they express their unique songs, calls, flight patterns or movements.
💎 Listen, and feel for, when the winds start to pick up in their intensity. 
💎 Listen to the gentle caress, or raging roar, of the Colorado River as it continues its timeless generosity and continuous flow. 
💎 Listen to the Canyon open up with wonder, as the golden hues of a sunset paint the horizon in an unearthly awe. 
💎 Listen as a ranger shares with us their passion for the Canyon, as we hear their voice rise with gusto and their palpable excitement. 
💎 Listen to, and learn from, the spoken (or unspoken) histories that intimately connect indigenous people through their sacred connection to this land and this place. 

Silence is not the absence of sound but the presence of one’s ability to listen. So, today, gift yourself some moments for silence. You may find that in silence, you open up to an entire world that is waiting to share in her musical splendor with you!

For additional listening and viewing opportunities from the Grand Canyon, check out our “Minute Out In It” video series, which features compelling stories (told without words) of the diverse soundscapes and landscapes throughout the park. https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/photosmultimedia/minute-out-in-it.htm

- AB

#WorldListeningDay #ListenUp #ListenIn #Soundscapes 

[#VideoDescription: Watching cloud shadows pass lazily across the layers of the canyon during the winter season.]

NPS Video/R. Lane

An audio-described version of the film can be found here: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=772643A9-9D3B-4B0E-B6DC-D90C1DEB262E

node.accessibility_caption: A uniformed park ranger holds an ice cream cone while smiling near the rim of an immense desert canyon.

node.text:
#NationalIceCreamDay 

I scream, you scream, we all scream if you stand too close to the rim! This National Ice Cream Day enjoy your favorite cone 6 feet from the canyon's edge. 

Lick Smart! Best times to consume ice cream are between 10 am and 4 pm, because you won't be busy hiking the canyon during those times, right?

Don’t forget, we are in a stage 2 fire ban. So, hold off on your campfires, put down those cigarettes, and pick up a sweet cone! 

Lastly, don’t feed the wildlife any of your delicious treats. This day is for humans only (sorry squirrels). 

NPS Photos/K. Kolstad, A. Rehkopf
#ImageDescription:
1. A uniformed park ranger holds an ice cream cone while smiling near the rim of an immense desert canyon.
2. These folks have the right idea! Several families gather under a shade structure to enjoy their various ice cream treats. (Shout out to the birthday boy in blue - Happy 16th!)

node.accessibility_caption: A uniformed park ranger holds an ice cream cone while smiling near the rim of an immense desert canyon.
Several families gather under a shade structure to enjoy their various ice cream treats.
Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 16, 2021. May be an image of deer, tree and nature.

node.text:
“When we're infused with either enthusiasm or awe or fondness, it changes what we see. It changes what we remember.” – Robert Legato

Waking up this morning to an elk calf, his mother, and the sunlight passing through a juniper tree—offers up a gentle reminder to connect with feelings of fondness and awe. 🌼

- AB 

#FridayFeeling

[#ImageDescription: A composite of 3 photos—rays of sunlight shining through a twisted juniper tree, an elk calf with white spots stands against a tree, a mother elk stands sunlit amongst the trees.]

Photo courtesy of A. Brill

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 15, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and nature.

node.text:
Many visitors choose to hike early in the morning. While this is a great way to beat the heat, not all of us are morning birds. Here are some tips on evening hikes for our night owls!

🕓 Start after 4pm!
↩️ Have a time when you will turn around! Right after sunset is a great point to decide to turn around, even if you don’t hit your destination.
🔦 Bring two headlamps and/or extra batteries, in case one runs out.
⛺ If walking through a campsite, dim your light or use a red light filter, so as not to disturb hikers trying to sleep.
🦌 Critters love to come out at night. Keep your distance and admire from afar.
🌃 Check the moon phase and moonrise so you know what the night sky will look like. A full moon can illuminate the canyon but dark sky can really show the Milky Way. 

Remember: No matter the time of day, any hike into (And especially out of!) Grand Canyon will be a strenuous hike, and it may take twice as much time to climb out of the canyon as it did to hike down. Be sure to bring proper footwear, plenty of water, and salty snacks. Every step you take down into the canyon is a strenuous step back up. There are no short cuts!

For more information and tips on hiking through Grand Canyon at any time of day, visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/hike-tips.htm

[Image Description: A hiker sitting down to rest at the edge of the inner gorge, watching the sun set. Photo courtesy of K. Kolstad.]

node.accessibility_caption: A rainbow appears amongst dark and light clouds appearing above vast and colorful canyon layers.

node.text:
“It is never the same, even from day to day, or even from hour to hour…Every passing cloud, every change in the position of the sun, recasts the whole.” – Clarence E. Dutton, 1885

We received some much-needed rain here last night! (0.4” Inner Canyon, 0.6” South Rim Village)

It was a welcome relief to watch those clouds roll through here—recasting the whole—and wake up this morning to petrichor (the smell of the earth after it rains). 💦🌱

- AB

NPS Photo/B. Cherry

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 12, 2021. May be an image of nature and sky.

node.text:
“There’s a second river. It’s the river that emerges after sunset in the form of a ribbon of stars.” – Kevin Fedarko 🌌

On this Mindful Monday, we wanted to share with you one visitor’s experience of visiting the Grand Canyon for his first time, and the value he now holds for the park and our night skies:

“Pristine dark skies are uncommon throughout the Eastern United States. When I first started astrophotography, I had my heart set on the Milky Way. I drove 2,000 miles from Alabama to the Grand Canyon to see the Milky Way with my own eyes. I couldn’t even tell you how many stars I was looking at that night! All I can say is [that] it’s a whole lot more than I have back at home.

However, when I got my first glimpse at the Milky Way I was speechless. Seeing our home galaxy fill up my field of view left me in awe. Stargazing at the Grand Canyon really reinforced my love for astronomy and astrophotography, and the fight against light pollution. If we all come together we could reduce the amount of light pollution and finally bring back our night skies. 

As for me, the Grand Canyon and its dark skies will forever be in my memories and my heart! As always, happy stargazing and clear skies!” – J. Evans

#MindfulMonday #MilkyWayGalaxy #InternationalDarkSkyPark #DarkSky #Astrophotography

[#ImageDescription: The Milky Way galaxy rises with colors of black, white and orange above a silhouette of trees over the Grand Canyon. Photo courtesy of J. Evans.]

node.accessibility_caption: Several people behind metal guardrails at a scenic overlook above a vast canyon landscape filled with smoke and dust. The distant rim of the canyon is hidden by the haze.

node.text:
For those who are asking, there is limited visibility from the South Rim this afternoon - caused by a mixture of smoke and dust. The sky cover for the Grand Canyon region is mostly high-level smoke from wildfires in Oregon. (Sunday, July 11, 2021) 

#azwx #Arizona #Fire #GrandCanyon #ExcessiveHeatWarning

node.accessibility_caption: Several people behind metal guardrails at a scenic overlook above a vast canyon landscape filled with smoke and dust. The distant rim of the canyon is hidden by the haze.
Looking down into a vast canyon towards a series of shilouetted ridgeline becoming engulfed by haze and smoke.
View past museum exhibits through a large picture window at a landscape that is shrouded in smoke. One peak is partially visible through thick haze.
A series of trail switchback descending a steep desert slope with cliff walls on all sides. Superimposed text reads: "Hot! 117 F/ 47 C.

node.text:
AN EXCESSIVE HEAT WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT INSIDE GRAND CANYON THIS WEEKEND 

* WHAT... Dangerously hot conditions with temperatures up to 120°F (49°C).

* WHERE... Lower elevations of the Grand Canyon, including Phantom Ranch and the Colorado River.

* WHEN... Until 8 PM MST SUNDAY, JULY 11, 2021.

* IMPACTS... Extreme heat will significantly increase the potential for heat related illnesses, particularly for those working or participating in outdoor activities.

PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

This warning is reserved for only the hottest days of the year and is issued when temperatures are expected to rise to dangerous levels.

Day hikers on Bright Angel Trail should descend no further than 1.5 miles. This weekend, water is not available at 1.5 mile resthouse. Hikers will need to carry their water with them

Between the hours of 10 AM and 4 PM, hiking and outdoor physical activity is discouraged. Hikers should attempt to be out of the canyon 

Backpackers with overnight camping permits should plan to be at Indian Garden or Bright Angel Campground between 10 am and 4 pm.

All hikers should have adequate gear, including a wide-brimmed hat, sunscreen, salty snacks, sufficient water and an electrolyte mix. Doubling your calorie intake helps maintain your energy.

Hike smart.

On the South Rim, the National Weather Service expects a high of 97 F (36 C).
